Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Flow Sorter Cytometer to Advance Marine Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs request funding to acquire a state-of-the-art cell-sorter flow cytometer. The use of flow cytometry has become central to most research in microbial oceanography, and critical in 'adaptive' sampling to assess shifts in population composition and function. The requested instrument is a modular, versatile, highspeed cell sorter that will enable the identification, enumeration and sorting of cells with subtle differences in their optical signatures. A novelty of the instrument is its unparalleled manual adjustment of detectors required to identify and sort organisms with subtle differences in their optical signatures, which is central in microbial oceanographic studies dealing with diversity, ecosystem function, biogeochemical effects of shifts in community composition, and evolution on marine microbial groups.

Broader Impacts:

The proposed flow cytometry facility will not only significantly further marine science research but will be available to engineering, medical, and anthropological colleagues. It will be used in a new class for undergraduate and graduate marine science students and in yearly workshops that will increase collaboration between UCSB personnel and other researchers. The PI has a good track record of providing access through media interviews and interactions with COSEE and school groups. A major value of the facility will be the creation of a new undergraduate and postgraduate course: 'Flow Cytometry Applications in Modern Microbial Oceanography'.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the creation of a flow cytometry facility to develop and improve approaches to explore single cell properties and address questions at different levels of organization (cellular, taxonomic, biogeochemical) in different disciplines. The work conducted involved identifying non-biological particles as well as cells, and ?sorting? (isolating) them into a volume of medium to create clonal cultures originating from a single cell. The majority of the users are oceanographers and molecular, cell and developmental biologists although engineers have also used the facility. The main focus of the work has been calcium carbonate producing phytoplanktonic organisms called coccolithophores, and the plates they produce (coccoliths). A main concern with these organisms is their fate under current and future scenarios of warming and ocean acidification among other human-driven stressors. The overall aim of these studies is to understand the relationships between chalk making (calcification) and the environment, and the role that diversity plays in maintaining populations of calcifiers. The rationale for studying these organisms stems from their role in ?locking away? carbon from the atmosphere into the ocean by making coccoliths (cells use carbon from the environment to make coccoliths) as they grow and divide. Other projects included identifying iridescent cells of mussels, and identifying specific groups of photosynthetic bacteria and phytoplankton, ?sorting? them into tubes to develop cultures that could then be used to determine their taxonomic identity and any changes in the population structure over time periods during which environmental conditions had changed. A particularly interesting aspect of this work was to use flow cytometry to unveil various stages of population development. 

 

The Influx Facility was central to fostering the participation of undergraduate and postgraduate students. Particular attention was paid to promoting the training of students from underrepresented cultural backgrounds through courses, training sessions and workshops. This training was conducted at the interface between bio-optics, microbial ecology, biogeochemistry and molecular biology, and had a direct impact on evolutionary biologists, biogeochemists, chemical and biological oceanographers, and climate scientists.
